Concepts.definition: A process that manifests as the worsening of a disease over time.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Patient refusal/noncompliance

Any unfavorable or unintended disease, sign, or symptom (including an abnormal laboratory finding) that is temporally associated with the use of a medical treatment or procedure, and that may or may not be considered related to the medical treatment or procedure. Such events can be related to the intervention, dose, route of administration, patient, or caused by an interaction with another drug(s) or procedure(s).

Concepts.definition: Any unfavorable or unintended disease, sign, or symptom (including an abnormal laboratory finding) that is temporally associated with the use of a medical treatment or procedure, and that may or may not be considered related to the medical treatment or procedure. Such events can be related to the intervention, dose, route of administration, patient, or caused by an interaction with another drug(s) or procedure(s).

PermissibleValues.valueDescription: Other Reason Complementary and Alternative Medicine

ValueMeaning.preferredName: Other Reason Complementary and Alternative Medicine
ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.: An explanation of the cause of some phenomenon or action.: Forms of treatment that are used in addition to (complementary) or instead of (alternative) standard treatments. These practices generally are not considered standard medical approaches. Standard treatments go through a long and careful research process to prove they are safe and effective, but less is known about most types of CAM. CAM may include dietary supplements, megadose vitamins, herbal preparations, special teas, acupuncture, massage therapy, magnet therapy, spiritual healing, and meditation.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
An explanation of the cause of some phenomenon or action.

A group of diverse medical and health care systems, practices, and products that are not presently considered to be part of conventional medicine. Complementary medicine as being used together with conventional medicine, whereas alternative medicine is used in place of conventional medicine. The National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine (NCCAM) groups CAM practices into four domains, recognizing there can be some overlap: mind-body medicine; biologically based practices, manipulative and body-based practices, and energy medicine. In addition, NCCAM studies CAM whole medical systems, which cut across all domains.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Scheduling

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The formal plan of an experiment or research activity, including the objective, rationale, design, materials and methods for the conduct of the study; intervention description, and method of data analysis.: Indicates that the patient was fully compliant with the full course of treatment.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Adverse event/side effects/complications
No treatment, per protocol criteria

Forms of treatment that are used in addition to (complementary) or instead of (alternative) standard treatments. These practices generally are not considered standard medical approaches. Standard treatments go through a long and careful research process to prove they are safe and effective, but less is known about most types of CAM. CAM may include dietary supplements, megadose vitamins, herbal preparations, special teas, acupuncture, massage therapy, magnet therapy, spiritual healing, and meditation.

Concepts.definition: A group of diverse medical and health care systems, practices, and products that are not presently considered to be part of conventional medicine. Complementary medicine as being used together with conventional medicine, whereas alternative medicine is used in place of conventional medicine. The National Center for Complementary and Alternative Medicine (NCCAM) groups CAM practices into four domains, recognizing there can be some overlap: mind-body medicine; biologically based practices, manipulative and body-based practices, and energy medicine. In addition, NCCAM studies CAM whole medical systems, which cut across all domains.

ValueMeaning.changeDescription: Concept annotation added for UPitt/TCGA.  Ylu, 01/30/2015.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: The branch of biology that studies the cellular aspects of heredity, especially the chromosomes. Includes the study of disease states caused by numerical and structural chromosome abnormalities.: A Resistance Process consists of activities of biologic molecules or complexes involved in processes that maintain immunity to, or counteract, defeat, or withstand the effects of, an antagonistic agent.

Concepts.definition: The branch of biology that studies the cellular aspects of heredity, especially the chromosomes. Includes the study of disease states caused by numerical and structural chromosome abnormalities.

A Resistance Process consists of activities of biologic molecules or complexes involved in processes that maintain immunity to, or counteract, defeat, or withstand the effects of, an antagonistic agent.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Disease progression before active treatment
Reduction due to toxicity
Interruption due to hypersensitivity
Delay per protocol
The loss or lack of continuation of subject participation after a study has officially closed.

Concepts.definition: The loss or lack of continuation of subject participation after a study has officially closed.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: No modification
A dose of medicine that was not taken at the prescribed dosing interval.

Concepts.definition: A dose of medicine that was not taken at the prescribed dosing interval.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Treatment not specified in a protocol.: Delay; time during which some action is awaited; inactivity resulting in something being put off until a later time.

Concepts.definition: Treatment not specified in a protocol.
Time during which some action is awaited; inactivity resulting in something being put off until a later time; the state of being slower or later.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A decrease in the number of neutrophils in the peripheral blood.

Concepts.definition: A decrease in the number of neutrophils in the peripheral blood.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A bile pigment that is a degradation product of HEME.: The condition of being elevated.

Concepts.definition: A dark orange, yellow pigment that is the product of the breakdown of iron in the blood; it is conjugated in the liver and excreted in the bile.
The condition of being elevated.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Activity measured as a test of liver function, 46/47-kDa homodimeric human Aspartate Aminotransferases (Class-I Pyridoxal-Phosphate-Dependent Aminotransferase Family) are pyridoxal phosphate-dependent enzymes involved in amino acid metabolism and in the urea and tricarboxylic acid cycles. (NCI): Activity measured as a test of liver function, human Glutamic-Pyruvate Transaminases (Alanine Aminotransferase Family) are pyridoxal phosphate-dependent enzymes involved in cellular nitrogen metabolism, amino acid metabolism, and liver gluconeogenesis. Glutamic Pyruvic Transaminases mediate conversion of major intermediate metabolites, catalyzing reversible transamination between alanine and alpha-ketoglutarate to form pyruvate and glutamate. (NCI): The condition of being elevated.

Concepts.definition: A family of pyridoxal phosphate-dependent enzymes involved in amino acid metabolism and in the urea and tricarboxylic acid cycles. Aspartate aminotransferase specifically and reversibly catalyzes the transfer of an amino group from L-aspartate to alpha-ketoglutarate forming oxaloacetate and L-glutamate.

A family of pyridoxal phosphate-dependent enzymes involved in cellular nitrogen metabolism, amino acid metabolism, and liver gluconeogenesis. Alanine aminotransferase specifically and reversibly catalyzes the transfer of an amino group from L-alanine to alpha-ketoglutarate forming pyruvate and L-glutamate.
The condition of being elevated.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: A syndrome observed in patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia treated with all-trans retinoic acid. It is characterized by weight gain, dyspnea, pleural and pericardial effusions, leukocytosis, and renal failure.

Concepts.definition: A syndrome observed in patients with acute promyelocytic leukemia treated with all-trans retinoic acid. It is characterized by weight gain, dyspnea, pleural and pericardial effusions, leukocytosis, and renal failure.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: An idiopathic disorder characterized by chronic increase in the intracranial pressure. It occurs predominantly in obese females of childbearing age. It is associated with papilledema.

Concepts.definition: An idiopathic disorder characterized by chronic increase in the intracranial pressure. It occurs predominantly in obese females of childbearing age. It is associated with papilledema.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Vo value exists.: The time interval between the start of the Q wave and the end of the T wave in the cardiac cycle as corrected with a non-specified correction formula.

Concepts.definition: Vo value exists.
The time interval between the start of the Q wave and the end of the T wave in the cardiac cycle as corrected with a non-specified correction formula.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.: Toxicity that impairs or damages the heart. This condition is often caused by the administration of a pharmaceutical agent that initiates a poisonous or toxic response in cardiac tissue.

Concepts.definition: Different than the one(s) previously specified or mentioned.
Toxicity that impairs or damages the heart. This condition is often caused by the administration of a pharmaceutical agent that initiates a poisonous or toxic response in cardiac tissue.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Protocol-defined dose escalation
A period of time to allow one agent to clear the body before another agent can be safely introduced.  Washout periods vary depending on the agents involved.

Concepts.definition: A period of time to allow one agent to clear the body before another agent can be safely introduced.  Washout periods vary depending on the agents involved.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: An explanation of the cause of some phenomenon or action.

Concepts.definition: An explanation of the cause of some phenomenon or action.

ReferenceDocuments.name: 1-COMMENT
ReferenceDocuments.description: This CDE may not be used for Off-Treatment or End of Treatment - only for modification or dose change; for Off-Treatment, see CDE #2186 with CDUS value for reporting
